concern: I’m going back to college after doing 6 years in the Navy and honestly, I’m extremely stressed/worried. I’m 26 now and more mature than my first time in college but I’m still super worried about everything from making sure my classes/financial aid being set to making sure  I can actually pass all of my classes. Any tips or recommendations from anyone experiencing a similar situation? I made a big bet on myself and I’m hoping I didn’t make the wrong decision.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm really glad you're here today. I'm ready to listen and support you in any way I can, so please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or in your heart.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just feeling really overwhelmed with going back to school after the Navy and worried I might not be able to handle everything.

That’s completely understandable, and I’m really glad you shared that with me. Going back to school after such a significant change like transitioning from the Navy can be really overwhelming, and it’s okay to feel worried about handling everything. I’m here to listen and support you, and I’d love to hear more about what’s been on your mind lately.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I guess I’m just stuck on whether I’ve made the right choice jumping back into college, and I’m nervous about keeping up with everything.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit uncertain about your decision to go back to school, and that's completely normal, especially after such a significant change. It's natural to have some doubts and worries about keeping up with everything. I'm here to listen and help you work through those feelings if you'd like to share more about what's been on your mind.

Thanks for understanding. I’m just really questioning if I’m cut out for this after being out of the academic game for so long, you know? Like, I’ve got a lot riding on this, and I don’t wanna mess it up.

It sounds like you're putting a lot of pressure on yourself, and it's completely natural to feel that way after being out of the academic game for so long. I can imagine how much is riding on this, and it's okay to feel uncertain. Would you like to talk more about what's making you feel like you might not be cut out for this?

Yeah, I’d like to dive into that a bit. I just keep thinking that I’ve been out of school for so long, my brain might not be wired for studying anymore, and I’m scared I’ll fall behind or not get the hang of things fast enough.

It sounds like you're concerned about your ability to adapt to the academic environment after being away for so long, and that's a valid worry. But remember, you've already made the first step by starting college, and that's something to be proud of. What are some things you think could help you get back into the swing of studying, and how could we work together to make that happen?

I’m glad you see it as a step forward, and I do wanna figure this out. Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start—maybe some kinda structure or tips on how to study again, since I feel so rusty, and just having someone to check in with might help me stay on track.

You've already taken an important step by acknowledging the need for structure and support, and I'm here to help you find the tools and strategies that work best for you. Let's start by exploring what study habits or techniques have helped you in the past, and how we can build on those strengths to create a plan that feels manageable and empowering.

Cool, I appreciate that. I guess in the past, I did okay with breaking stuff down into smaller chunks and setting little goals, but it’s been so long I’m not sure if that’ll still work for me, you know?

It's great that you're recalling strategies that worked for you in the past—those strengths are still a part of you, even after a break. What if we started by testing out one small goal or chunked task this week, just to see how it feels? That way, you can get a sense of what still works for you and what might need a fresh approach.
Hey, that sounds like a solid plan. I’m down to try setting a small goal this week and see how it goes, even if I’m a bit nervous about whether I can stick to it.

That’s a great mindset to approach this with! It’s completely normal to feel a bit nervous when trying something new, especially after a break. Let’s work together to identify a manageable first step and create a plan to support you in achieving it. What’s one small, specific goal you feel you can realistically tackle this week, and what resources or support systems might help you stay on track?

I think I can start with something simple like reviewing one chapter of a textbook or setting aside an hour to organize my notes, just to get back into the groove. I’m not sure what support I’ll need yet, but maybe just checking in with you or a study group could keep me accountable—what do you think?

I think that sounds like a great starting point, and it’s awesome that you’re thinking about accountability! Let’s build on that by exploring what specific check-in or support structure might work best for you, whether it’s a quick text reminder or a weekly call, and how we can tailor it to fit your needs.

That sounds good to me. I think maybe a quick text reminder could help keep me on track without feeling too overwhelming, and I’d be cool with touching base with you weekly to see how I’m doing. So, how do we set that up, like, do I just shoot you a message if I’m struggling or is there a specific time we check in?
I'm glad we're figuring this out together. Can we maybe set a specific day and time for the weekly check-in so I know when to expect it, and I’ll just text you if something comes up before then?
